[[Bogota]] and [[North Miami]] | language = Spanish and English | website = {{URL|http://www.artnexus.com/}} | issn = 0121-5639 | eissn = | oclc = 32047179 }} '''ArtNexus''' is the leading magazine to cover the [[contemporary art]] of [[Latin America]].{{cite web|title=ArtNexus|url=http://www.arteba.org/web/?p=3759&lang=en|work=arteBA Fundación|accessdate=25 September 2014}} From its documentation center in Bogota, the magazine covers visual art and [[architecture]].[http://artlima.pe/2013/institucionales-o-empresariales/ Art Lima] By publishing in both Spanish and English, the magazine fulfilled its goal to be "The Nexus Between Latin America and the Rest of the World."{{cite book|last1=Cole|first1=Jim|last2=Stankus|first2=Tony|title=Journals of the Century |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Pv7sAgAAQBAJ&pg=PA129&lpg=PA129&dq=Fundaci%C3%B3n+ArtNexus&source=bl&ots=j1qxpb_MFk&sig=XaIs2tNqfpjuHKBpnhMEqdR3rq8&hl=en&sa=X&ei=XzQiVOqqO8m2yASjhYHIAw&ved=0CDgQ6AEwBTge#v=onepage&q=Art%20Nexus&f=false|date=2013|publisher=Routledge|location=New York|isbn=978-0-789-01134-3|page=129|accessdate=24 September 2014}} ==Structure and mission== The current editor and publisher is Celia S de Birbragher.{{cite web |title=ArtNexus |url= http://www.artnexus.com/ |website=Be Live |publisher=Belive Colombia |accessdate=21 July 2015}} The quarterly magazine is funded by two non-profit organizations, Fundación ArtNexus in Colombia and ArtNexus Foundation in the United States.{{cite web |title=ArtNexus Foundation |url= http://www.belive.co/artnexus-foundation/ |website=Be Live |publisher=Belive Colombia |accessdate=25 September 2014}} The magazine and foundation's United States location is in [[North Miami, Florida]]. The foundations sponsor scholarship, research archives, and public symposia. In 2011, Funación ArtNexus earned a $127,500 grant from the [[Getty Foundation]] to host ''Intellectual Networks: Art and Politics in Latin America'', in which scholars researched artistic and scholarly networks throughout Latin America during the mid-twentieth century.{{cite web|title=Connecting Art Histories|url=http://www.getty.edu/foundation/initiatives/current/cah/cah_grantsawarded.html|website=The Getty Foundation|publisher=J. Paul Getty Trust|accessdate=25 September 2014}} This resulted in a major exhibition of historical documents at the [[Museo de Arquitectura Leopoldo Rother]] at the [[National University of Colombia]].{{cite news|title=Arte y política del siglo XX en la Universidad Nacional|url=http://www.eltiempo.com/archivo/documento/CMS-13770459|accessdate=25 September 2014|publisher=El Tiempo|date=2 April 2014}} ArtNexus hosts events at major Latin American art fairs, including the International Art Fair of Bogota{{cite news|last1=Corzo|first1=Liliana|title=Artbo cierra con Artnexus|url=http://www.jetset.com.co/sociedad/bogota/galeria/fiesta-de-cierre-artbo-artnexus/92288|accessdate=25 September 2014|work=JetSet|date=28 October 2013}} and [[Art Basel Miami]].{{cite web|title=ArtNexus Party: St. Regis Resort|url=http://www.myartguides.com/art-basel-miami-beach-2012/events/item/332-artnexus-party|website=Art Basel Miami Beach 2012|publisher=Miami Art Guide 2012|accessdate=25 September 2014}} ArtNexus also hosts awards for outstanding living Latin American artists.{{cite web|title=Nicole Franchy|url=http://hisk.edu/w/Artnexus|publisher=Higher Institute for Fine Arts|accessdate=25 September 2014}} It also hosts art exhibitions at Espacio Art Nexus in the [[Las Nieves, Bogota|Las Nieves]] neighborhood of Bogota.{{cite news|title=El conflicto en América Latina, en una muestra de arte|url=http://www.eltiempo.com/entretenimiento/arte-y-teatro/realidades-en-conflicto-se-exhibe-en-el-espacio-art-nexus/14275867|accessdate=25 September 2014|work=El Tiempo|agency=GDA|date=20 July 2014}} ==Background== The magazine was founded in 1976 in [[Bogota, Colombia]].{{cite web|title=Art Nexus|url=http://www.arte-sur.org/press/art-nexus/|website=art-sur.org|publisher=Artsur|accessdate=25 September 2014}} Initially it was named ''Arte en Colombia'' and focused on [[Colombian art]]; however, in 1991, it changed its name to ''ArtNexus'' and expanded its scope to include the entire contemporary [[Latin American art]] scene.{{cite web|title=Art Nexus, arte en Colombia|url=http://www.prismatv.unal.edu.co/nc/detalle-serie/detalle-programa/article/art-nexus-arte-en-colombia.html|website=Canal Prisma TV|publisher=Universidad Nacional de Colombia|accessdate=25 September 2014}} {{clear}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.artnexus.com/ Official website] [[Category:1976 establishments in Colombia]] [[Category:Architecture magazines]] [[Category:Art magazines]] [[Category:Colombian art]] [[Category:Colombian magazines]] [[Category:Contemporary art magazines]] [[Category:Latin American art]] [[Category:Magazines established in 1976]] [[Category:Media in Bogotá]] [[Category:Quarterly magazines]] [[Category:Spanish-language magazines]]

'''Baharestan''', (in Persian: بهارستان), (pronounced as ''Bǎhārestān'' or ''Bahaarestaan'') (meaning ''the land of spring'', ''the spring orchard'' or ''the spring garden''), is a [[Persian language|Persian]] book written by [[Jami]] that contains [[prose]]. It has stories, [[Narrative|tales]] and moral advice mainly in prose, but also in [[poetry]]. Baharestan is divided into eight [[chapter (books)|chapter]]s, an introduction, and a final part. Each of its chapters is called a ''rowzeh'' (from [[Arabic]] rawzah, meaning ''paradise'' or ''heaven''). Jami wrote this book in a year in the 9th century after [[Hegira|Muhammad's departure]] to Medina. In the introduction of Baharestan, Jami stated that he had written this book in the style of [[Saadi Shirazi]]'s [[Gulistan (book)|Gulistan]] for his son who was ten years old at the time and was studying. Baharestan has content about [[Sufism]] and [[mysticism]]. There are 469 [[Verse (poetry)|verses]] of poetry in this book; 16 verses being in Arabic and the rest in Persian. Baharestan has [[saj']] in its texts and the type of its prose is [[rhymed prose]]; i.e. it is rhythmic. Each chapter in Baharestan has a specific topic; for example, in the seventh chapter, the topic is the life and the biography of some poets.

{{Other uses|Cambia (disambiguation){{!}}Cambia}} {{Use Australian English|date=July 2015}} {{Use dmy dates|date=March 2018}} {{Infobox organization |name=Cambia |logo=Cambia logo.png |logo_size=220px |type=[[NGO|Non-Governmental Organisation]] with the [[Food and Agriculture Organization|Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations]] and [[World Intellectual Property Organization|WIPO]]. [[Not-for-profit organisation]] with the [[Australian Securities and Investments Commission]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cambia.org/daisy/cambia/about/592/589.html |title=Cambia's Structure |accessdate=2010-01-08 }}</ref> |founded_date=1992 |founder=[[Richard Anthony Jefferson]] |location=[[Canberra]] and [[Brisbane]] Australia |focus=[[Open innovation]], [[life sciences]], [[intellectual property]] |Non-profit_slogan=Solving the Problem of Problem Solving (formerly, Enabling Innovation) |homepage=[http://www.cambia.org/ www.cambia.org] }}
'''Cambia''' is an [[Australia]]n-based global [[non-profit]] [[social enterprise]] focusing on [[open science]], [[biology]], innovation system reform and [[intellectual property]]. Its projects include the [[Patent Lens]], its successor [http://www.lens.org The Lens], and the [[Biological Innovation for Open Society]] Initiative.
Cambia derives its name from the [[Spanish language|Spanish]] [[verb]] ''cambiar'', to change.<ref>https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/cambiar</ref>
==History== Cambia was established in 1992 by [[Richard Anthony Jefferson]], a leading molecular biologist responsible for the invention of the [[GUS reporter system]], with substantial early participation by Steven G Hughes, [https://www.linkedin.com/pub/kate-wilson/27/41a/275 Kate J. Wilson], Andrzej Kilian, Chris A. Fields and Sujata Lakhani. Jefferson describes his vision to found a non-profit organisation in ''Innovations'',<ref>{{cite journal|doi=10.1162/itgg.2006.1.4.13|title=Science as Social Enterprise: The CAMBIA BiOS Initiative|journal=Innovations|date=Fall 2006|first=Richard|last=Jefferson|volume=1|issue=4|pages=13–44|id= |url=http://www.cambia.org/daisy/bios/3067/version/default/part/AttachmentData/data/INNOV0104_pp13-44_innovations-in-practice_jefferson.pdf|format=|accessdate=2010-01-06 }}</ref> to provide more efficient and effective tools to solve the problems of agriculture and society.
In 1992, Cambia relocated to [[Canberra]], [[Australia]] from The Netherlands, to oversee and troubleshoot the [[Rockefeller Foundation]]'s [[rice]] biotechnology network in Asia. During this time, Jefferson, Wilson and the growing Cambia team visited hundreds of laboratories to help develop, improve, and apply biotechnology capabilities, particularly pertaining to rice. Cambia offered scientific courses and workshops, and increasing assistance in [[Intellectual Property]] management. Cambia's ethic was influenced by Jefferson's early years in enabling technology invention and distribution, but greatly refined through increasing awareness of socially and scientifically complex systems and using new thinking about biological evolution (including the [[Hologenome theory of evolution|Hologenome Theory of Evolution]]) as models for institution building and collaboration.
Cambia became one of the first social enterprises to use a hybrid licensing model to fund its public good activities. By selectively patenting important technologies, then creating tiered licensing models for their use, Cambia was able to ensure all parties fair access, but larger licensees would be required to pay more for their non-exclusive use, thus subsidising new developments and distribution and support to less wealthy users, including small enterprises and the public sector in the developing world. This model - developed also by the social entrepreneur [[David Green (social entrepreneur)|David Green]] for universal access to eye care - is now becoming a pillar of social enterprise function.
Over time Cambia's focus moved away from biotechnology and towards innovation systems and Intellectual Property. The Patent Lens and its successor The Lens are now the primary focus of Cambia. Cambia's goal has always been to enable and democratise innovation and their move towards free and open tools that help people understand intellectual property landscapes is a continuation of those values. In this way they have changed from a wet-science research institute into a strategic system-changing social enterprise.
==Projects== Cambia's work to freely distribute scientific tools and techniques gave rise to the [[Biological Innovation for Open Society|Biological Open Source (BiOS)]] Initiative in 2005. Through an open-source biotechnology license and [[Material Transfer Agreement]] (MTA) developed in 2005-2007, BiOS sought to establish [[freedom to operate]] for innovators by providing and exemplifying legal instruments by which innovators could collaboratively use intellectual property protection as a means to share and jointly improve technology for wider utility. BiOS was built on the back of Jefferson's invention of the GUS-based reporter system and the creation of TransBacter,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.patentlens.net/daisy/bioforge_transbacter/3187.html |title=TransBacter Project |accessdate=2010-01-10 }}</ref> a work-around for the creation of transgenic plants bypassing the highly patented [[Agrobacterium]] genus.<ref>{{cite journal|title=Gene transfer to plants by diverse species of bacteria|journal=Nature|date=2005-02-10|first=Wim|last=Broothaerts|author2=Heidi J. Mitchell |author3=Brian Weir |author4=Sarah Kaines |author5=Leon M.A. Smith |author6=Wei Jang |author7=Jorge E. Mayer |author8=Carolina Roa-Rodriguez |author9=Richard A. Jefferson |pmid=15703747|volume=433|issue=7026|pages=629–633|doi= 10.1038/nature03309|url=http://www.nature.com/nature/journal/v433/n7026/full/nature03309.html|accessdate=2010-01-07 }}</ref>
Another of Cambia's projects was the development in 2001 <ref>Jaccoud D, Peng K, Feinstein D, Kilian A (February 2001). "Diversity arrays: a solid state technology for sequence information independent genotyping". Nucleic Acids Res. 29 (4): E25. {{doi|10.1093/nar/29.4.e25}}. {{PMC|29632}}. {{PMID|11160945}}</ref> by then Chief Scientist Andrzej Kilian of [[Diversity Arrays Technology]], a solid state sequence agnostic genotyping technology that was spun off into a company, DArT, Pty Ltd to perform agricultural genotyping services to the plant breeding community.
A principal current project of Cambia is the free full-text online patent search and exploration facility and knowledge resource, The Lens (previously the Patent Lens). Launched in 2000 with funding from the Rockefeller Foundation as a US agricultural patent search facility, and substantially expanded in 2005-2007 to encompass patent documents from multiple jurisdictions and all domains, and information on the linkages between patent applications and the status of granted patents, the Patent Lens allowed free searching of almost 10 million full-text patent documents. It was distinguished as being the only not-for-profit facility of its kind, with international coverage and integrated links to non-patent literature. The Lens was launched in 2013 as the successor to the [[Patent Lens]], making strides in the visual presentation of patent analysis and workspace management; it is the only global patent site with fully open, shareable, annotatable and re-usable data collections.
It also features an open [[biological patent]] facility, PatSeq, led by Professor [[Osmat Jefferson]],<ref>Osmat A Jefferson, Deniz Köllhofer, Thomas H Ehrich & Richard A Jefferson, Transparency tools in gene patenting for informing policy and practice. Nature Biotechnology 31, 1086–1093 (2013) {{doi|10.1038/nbt.2755}}</ref> with many advanced tools for searching and analysing biological sequences found in patents, to render gene patenting more transparent. The facility has mapped sequences disclosed in gene patents onto the genomes of humans, mice, maize, rice, soybean and others.
==Governance== Cambia is [[social enterprise]], and is a registered [[NGO|Non-Governmental Organisation]] with the [[Food and Agriculture Organization| Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations]] and a registered observer with the [[World Intellectual Property Organization]]. Within Australia, Cambia is registered with the [[Australian Securities and Investment Commission]] (ASIC) as a not-for-profit company limited by guarantee.
Cambia’s governance is overseen by a Board of Directors,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cambia.org/daisy/cambia/4759.html |title=Cambia Board of Directors |accessdate=2010-01-10 }}</ref> according to its constitution.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cambia.org/daisy/cambia/about/592/1809.html |title=Constitution of Cambia - A Company Limited by Guarantee |accessdate=2010-01-10 }}</ref>
==Locations== As of July 2012, Cambia now operates principally from headquarters in Canberra, ACT at the [[NICTA]] (National ICT Australia) facility, with some staff based in [[Brisbane]], Australia, at the [[Queensland University of Technology]]. Before its move to Brisbane in 2008, where it operated for four years, Cambia was located on the [[Black Mountain (Australian Capital Territory)|Black Mountain]] research campus of the [[CSIRO]]. Its glasshouse facilities were housed at the [[Australian National University]] campus.

{{Infobox song | name = Cambodia | cover = Kim Wilde - Cambodia.jpg | alt = | type = single | artist = [[Kim Wilde]] | album = [[Select (album)|Select]] | B-side = Watching for Shapes | released = 2 November 1981 | format = 7", 12" | recorded = 1981 | studio = | venue = | genre = [[Synthpop]], [[New wave music|new wave]] | length = 3:56 (7" Version)
7:13 (Album Version, including "Reprise") | label = [[RAK Records|RAK]] | writer = [[Ricky Wilde]], [[Marty Wilde]] | producer = [[Ricky Wilde]] | prev_title = [[Water on Glass]] | prev_year = 1981 | next_title = [[View from a Bridge]] | next_year = 1982 }} "'''Cambodia'''" is the fourth single by British singer [[Kim Wilde]]. It was released at the end of 1981; a year in which Wilde had already scored three highly successful hit singles and a best-selling debut album. The single was another international success, topping the charts in Sweden and Switzerland and hitting the top ten in several other nations. It was released on the 7" format but also as a 12" single in Germany, although not in a remixed or extended version. The B-side of both releases was an exclusive non-album track called "Watching for Shapes". "Cambodia" was later included on Wilde's second album, ''[[Select (album)|Select]]'', which was released six months after the single in May 1982. The album version of "Cambodia" runs for 7:13 minutes, as it is teamed with a more uptempo instrumental version of the song, called "Reprise". Musically and lyrically, "Cambodia" showed a change in direction for Wilde from the [[new wave music|new wave]] feel of her debut album. The song was mainly synth-driven, with oriental-sounding percussion. The lyrics were inspired by the [[Operation Menu]] bombing campaign of Cambodia by the United States during the [[Vietnam War]]. It has sold 1,080,000 copies in France.http://www.infodisc.fr/Ventes_Chansons_Tout_Temps.php ==Background== {{Empty section|date=September 2018}} ==Composition== {{Listen|pos=left|filename=Kim Wilde - Cambodia sample.ogg|title="Cambodia"|description=A 21-second sample of "Cambodia".|format =[[Ogg]]}} "Cambodia" was written by [[Marty Wilde]] and [[Ricki Wilde]] and has a length of seven minutes and thirteen seconds. ''[[The Independent]]''{{'}}s Chris Mugan found the song reminiscent of a ''[[film noir]]''. Stewart Mason of [[AllMusic]] noted that the song lacks the [[bubblegum pop]] influence present on Wilde's [[Kim Wilde (album)|self-titled debut album]], and is instead more synthesizer-driven. Matt James of ''[[PopMatters]]'' felt that the song was an attempt by Kim Wilde to prove that she could tackle serious issues, in the vein of [[The Human League]]'s "[[The Lebanon (song)|The Lebanon]]" (1984) and [[Sting (musician)|Sting]]'s "[[Russians (song)|Russians]]" (1985).{{cite web | url = https://www.popmatters.com/164907-parallels-xii-2495801812.html | title = Parallels: XII| date = 2012-11-12 | accessdate = 2018-03-16 | last = James | first = Matt | work = [[PopMatters]]}} ==Critical reception== According to [[Yahoo!]], songs like "Cambodia", "[[View from a Bridge]]" (1982) and Wilde's version of "[[You Keep Me Hangin' On]]" (1986) brought her "very close to [the] hearts" of [[Australians]].{{cite web | url = https://au.news.yahoo.com/sunrise/a/33101959/kim-wilde-howard-jones-return-to-australia/ | title = Kim Wilde & Howard Jones Return to Australia| date = 2016-10-04 | accessdate = 2018-03-16| work = [[Yahoo! News]]}} ''The Independent''{{'}}s Chris Mugan deemed the song one of Wilde's "eighties classics" alongside "Kids in America".{{cite web | url = https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/music/reviews/kim-wilde-gig-review-poised-halfway-between-sparkly-housewife-and-down-to-earth-celeb-9022400.html | title = Kim Wilde, gig review: 'poised halfway between sparkly housewife and down-to-earth celeb'| date = 2013-12-23 | accessdate = 2018-03-16 | last = Mugan | first = Chris | work = [[The Independent]]}} In the ''[[Encyclopedia of Popular Music]]'', [[Colin Larkin (writer)|Colin Larkin]] opined that Wilde tried "a more adventurous sound" with "Cambodia," indicating that she was "an exciting talent."{{cite web|last=Larkin|first=Colin|title=Encyclopedia of Popular Music|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=_NNmFiUnSmUC&pg=RA89-PA2005&dq=kim+wilde+cambodia&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjntaDOo_HZAhWPmlkKHdWkAj44ChDoAQg4MAQ#v=onepage&q=kim%20wilde%20cambodia&f=false|publisher=Omnibus Press|date=2011|accessdate=March 16, 2018}} The ''[[Ipswich Star]]''{{'s}} Wayne Savage said that "Cambodia" and "[[Chequered Love]]" (1981) are "seminal smashes" which prove that Wilde "struck gold more often than not."{{cite web | url = http://www.ipswichstar.co.uk/what-s-on/my-kids-ignore-my-music-advice-laughs-80s-chart-topper-kim-wilde-ahead-of-ipswich-and-southend-shows-1-5428971 | title = My kids ignore my music advice laughs 80s chart-topper Kim Wilde ahead of Ipswich and Southend shows| date = 2018-03-10 | accessdate = 2018-03-16 | last = Savage | first = Wayne | work = [[Ipswich Star]]}} ''[[Vogue (magazine)|Vogue]]''{{'s}} Rachel Hahn called the song an "underrated classic".{{cite web | url = https://www.vogue.com/article/paris-fashion-week-2018-best-runway-music-playlist | title = Listen to a Playlist of Paris Fashion Week's Best Runway Music| date = 2018-10-05 | accessdate = 2018-03-16 | last = Hahn | first = Rachel | work = ''[[Vogue (magazine)|Vogue]]''}} Stewart Mason of [[AllMusic]] noted that "Kim Wilde's second album didn't score any hits on the level of the debut's 'Kids in America,' although the dramatic 'Cambodia' was a sort of cult favorite in some circles."{{cite web | url = http://www.allmusic.com/album/select-r2300522/review | title = Kim Wilde Select review | accessdate = 2012-05-10 | last = Mason | first = Stewart | work = [[AllMusic]] | publisher = [[Rovi Corporation]]}} Writing for the same website, John Bush called the track a "fan favorite" and an "odd, chilling attempt to record a dirge for Southeastern Asia."{{cite web | url = https://www.allmusic.com/album/the-very-best-of-kim-wilde-mw0000397732 | title = The Very Best of Kim Wilde | accessdate = 2018-03-16 | last = Bush | first = John | work = [[AllMusic]] | publisher = [[Rovi Corporation]]}} In ''The Legacies of Jean-Luc Godard'', Douglas Morrey wrote that "'Cambodia' is not...a particularly moving record". In his review of ''[[The Singles Collection 1981–1993]]'' in ''All Music Guide to Rock: The Definitive Guide to Rock, Pop, and Soul'', Mike DeGagne wrote that "Only the unbecoming 'Cambodia' and the hollowed out '[[Child Come Away]]' should be avoided on this collection, as both lack the spirit that Wilde usually packs." ==Track listing== # Cambodia (3:56) # Watching for Shapes (3:42) ==Charts== {{col-begin}} {{col-2}} ===Weekly charts=== {| class="wikitable sortable plainrowheaders" |- !Chart (1981-1982) !Peak

{{Multiple| {{news release|1=article|date=January 2015}} {{COI|date=December 2014}} }} '''David Roberts Art Foundation''' (DRAF) is a non-profit centre for contemporary art in central [[London]].<ref>Hastings, Sophie (21 February 2014). [http://www.gq-magazine.co.uk/entertainment/articles/2014-02-/21/david-roberts-art-foundation-geographies-of-contamination-camden "Meet the property developer putting care into collecting"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141218173134/http://www.gq-magazine.co.uk/entertainment/articles/2014-02-/21/david-roberts-art-foundation-geographies-of-contamination-camden |date=2014-12-18 }}. [http://www.gq-magazine.co.uk/ ''GQ Magazine''].</ref><ref>Coles, Alex (3 October 2014). "But Is It Art?". [https://www.standard.co.uk/lifestyle/esmagazine/ ''Evening Standard Magazine''].</ref><ref>Trebuchet. (13 January 2014). "Hanging Offence: David Roberts Art Foundation". [http://www.trebuchet-magazine.com/ ''Trebuchet Magazine''.]</ref>
==Programme== DRAF produces art works, exhibitions, performances and events open free to the public.<ref>Andrews, Kate (23 April 2014). "[http://www.bmw-art-guide.com/a-collection-which-never-sleeps/ A Collection Which Never Sleeps]". [http://www.bmw-art-guide.com ''BMW Art Guide''].</ref><ref>Hurford Brown, Debra (3 May 2014). "The Collector". WeekendLife.</ref><ref>(October 2014). "[http://www.indigomemoirs.com/directory/best-contemporary-art-galleries-london/ Best Contemporary Art Galleries London]". [http://www.indigomemoirs.com/ ''Indigo Memoirs''].</ref> Over the last seven years, DRAF has collaborated with over 680 emerging and established artists and curators, including [[Phyllida Barlow]], [[Bruce McLean]], [[Danh Vo]], Benoit Maire, Nina Beier and [[Sarah Lucas]].<ref>Snow, Phillipa (October 2014). "[http://www.artslantstreet.com/articles/show/41077 Frieze Camden: Sarah Lucas' Fried Eggs]". [http://www.artslantstreet.com/ ''Art Slant''].</ref><ref>Quaintance, Morgan (7 October 2014). "[http://artreview.com/reviews/web_review_oct_2014_nina_beier/ Review: Nina Beier]". [http://artreview.com/ ''Art Review''].</ref>
==Building== Founded in 2007 by British collector [[David Roberts (art collector)|David Roberts]] and directed by curator Vincent Honoré, DRAF originally occupied a gallery space on [[Great Titchfield Street]] in Fitzrovia.<ref>Muñoz-Alonso, Lorena (12 September 2012). [http://thisistomorrow.info/articles/interview-with-vincent-honore-part-1 "Interview with Vincent Honoré"]. [http://thisistomorrow.info/ ''This is Tomorrow''].</ref><ref>Mansfield, Susan (03 May 2014). [http://www.scotsman.com/lifestyle/arts/visual-arts/art-collector-david-roberts-on-his-new-gallery-1-3397761 "Art collector David Roberts on his new gallery".] [http://www.scotsman.com/ ''The Scostman''],</ref> It moved in 2012 to its current headquarters in Mornington Crescent, a 19th-century converted furniture factory with 500 sq m exhibition space on the ground floor. In Autumn 2015, DRAF will expand to include a substantial new first floor space dedicated to live events.{{Citation needed|date=July 2015}}
==Performances and live events== DRAF focuses on performance, animating art works, spaces and situations through commissions from artists, choreographers, musicians and writers. They hold an annual evening of performances in October during the Frieze Art Fair. In 2014, Quinn Latimer & Megan Rooney, Joe Moran, Sarah Lucas, planningtorock and Eloise Hawser performed to 1,000 guests.<ref>(16 October 2014). "[https://world.timeout.com/events/evening-of-performances-with-quinn-latimer-megan-rooney-joe-moran-planningtorock-sarah-lucas-and Evening of Performances with Quinn Latimer & Megan Rooney, Joe Moran, planningtorock, Sarah Lucas and Eloise Hawser]". [https://world.timeout.com/ ''Time Out''].</ref> In 2013, the evening featured Florence Peake, Michael Dean, Juliette Blightman, [[Rodney Graham]] and [[Kim Gordon]].
Year-round talks and live events in collaboration with institutions and universities discuss emerging questions with artists, specialists and audiences.
==Curators’ Series== The Curators’ Series invites an independent guest curator to produce a major exhibition at DRAF, and has previously hosted Cylena Simonds (UK), Raimundas Malasauskas (Lithuania), Mihnea Mircan (Romania), Mathieu Copeland (UK), Simone Menegoi and Chris Sharp (Italy and US), Pablo Leon de la Barra (Mexico), and Vivian Ziherl (Australia) & Natasha Ginwala (India).<ref>Rui An, Ho (September/October 2014). "A Special Arrow was Shot on the Neck...". Page 145. ''artasiapacific''.</ref> The eighth guest curator will be Christine Eyene (Cameroon) in summer 2015.
==David Roberts Collection== DRAF is responsible for the David Roberts Collection, a body of over 2,000 artworks by 600 artists. The Collection exists independently in parallel to DRAF’s public programme, offering a resource for research and presentation.
==Structure== DRAF is a registered charity (no. 1119738) and is supported by Edinburgh House Estates Limited.

'''Design controls''' designates the application of a formal [[Design management|methodology]] to the conduct of [[new product development|product development]] activities. It is often mandatory (by regulation) to implement such practice when designing and developing products within regulated industries (e.g. [[medical devices]]).
== Medical devices ==
Since 1990, the [[Food and Drug Administration]] (FDA) has required that [[medical device]] manufacturers that want to market certain categories of medical devices in the USA follow Design Control requirements (21 CFR 820.30). At a high level, this regulation requires: * [[Design and development planning]] * [[Design input]], including intended use and [[Voice of the customer|user needs]] (also known as customer attributes) * [[Design output]], including evaluation of conformance to design input requirements through: ** Design verification confirming that the design output meets the design input requirements ("did we design the device right?") ** Design validation ensuring that the devices conform to defined user needs and intended uses ("did we design the right device?") * [[Design review]] * [[Design transfer]] ensuring that the device design is correctly translated into production specifications * [[Design change|Design changes]] * [[Design history file]], a demonstration that the design was developed according to the approved design plan and 21 CFR 820.30.
The [[Medical Devices Directive]] (MDD 93/42/EEC) similarly lists several requirements regarding the design of a medical device. '''[[ISO 13485]]''' is a voluntary standard that contains section 7.3 Design and Development recommending which procedures should be put in place by manufacturers in order to have a quality system that will comply with MDD 93/42/EEC.
The objective of Design Controls, in this context, is to require that manufacturers follow a methodologically-sound process to develop a medical device, with the intent of improving the probability that the device will reach an acceptable level of [[efficacy]] and safety.
== Design input == Examples of design input<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.fda.gov/downloads/Training/CDRHLearn/UCM529614.pdf|title=Design Controls|last=Joseph|first=Tartal|date=|website=FDA|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=June 15, 2017}}</ref>: {| class="wikitable" !Device functions !Human factors |- |Physical characteristics |Labeling & packaging |- |Performance |Maintenance |- |Safety |Sterilization |- |Reliability |Compatibility |- |Performance standards |Environmental limits |- |Regulatory requirements | |}
==References and external links== * 21 CFR 820.30 on the FDA website [http://www.accessdata.fda.gov/scripts/cdrh/cfdocs/cfCFR/CFRSearch.cfm?CFRPart=820&showFR=1&subpartNode=21:8.0.1.1.12.3] * MDD 93/42/EEC [http://eur-lex.europa.eu/LexUriServ/LexUriServ.do?uri=CONSLEG:1993L0042:20071011:en:PDF]

{{Refimprove|date=June 2016}} {{Infobox song | Name = El Cóndor Pasa | Cover = | Caption = | Type = | Artist = | Album = | Published = 1913 | Released = | track_no = | Recorded = | Genre = | Length = | Writer = | Composer = [[Daniel Alomía Robles]] | Lyricist = | Language = [[English language|English]], [[Spanish language|Spanish]] | Label = | Producer = | Tracks = | prev = | prev_no = | next = | next_no = | Misc = }} '''El Cóndor Pasa''' ({{IPA-es|el ˈkondoɾ pasa|pron}}, [[Spanish language|Spanish]] for "The [[Andean condor|Condor]] Passes") is an [[orchestra]]l [[musical composition|musical piece]] from the [[zarzuela]] ''[[El Cóndor Pasa (play)|El Cóndor Pasa]]'' by the [[Peru]]vian composer [[Daniel Alomía Robles]], written in 1913 and based on traditional [[Andean music]], specifically [[folk music]] from [[music of Peru|Peru]]. Since then, it has been estimated that around the world, more than 4000 versions of the melody have been produced, along with 300 sets of lyrics. In 2004, Peru declared this song as part of the national cultural heritage.{{cite web|url=http://www.latinoamerica-online.info/cult04/musica06.04.html |title=musica musique musica |website=Latinoamerica-online.info |date=2004-04-13 |accessdate=2016-06-18}} This song is now considered the second national anthem of Peru.{{citation needed|date=October 2015}} It is the best-known Peruvian song in the English-speaking world due to a 1970 cover by [[Simon & Garfunkel]] on their ''[[Bridge over Troubled Water]]'' album. Their version is called "'''El Cóndor Pasa (If I Could)'''". ==Original zarzuela version== In 1913, Peruvian songwriter [[Daniel Alomía Robles]] composed "El Cóndor Pasa", and the song was first performed publicly at the Teatro Mazzi in [[Lima]].{{cite web|url=http://www.acuarela.se/ElCondorPasa.htm |title="El Cóndor Pasa" patrimonio cultural de la nación |website=Acuarela.se |accessdate=2016-06-18}} The song was originally a musical piece in the Peruvian zarzuela (musical play), ''[[El cóndor pasa (zarzuela)|El cóndor pasa]]''. Its music was composed by Daniel Alomía Robles in 1913 and its script was written by Julio de La Paz (pseudonym of the Limenian dramatist Julio Baudouin). The piano arrangement of this play's most famous melody was legally registered on May 3, 1933 by The Edward B. Marks Music Corp. in the [[Library of Congress]], under the number 9643. The zarzuela is written in prose and consists of one musical play and two acts. In July 2013, the Colectivo Cultural Centenario El Cóndor Pasa cultural association re-edited the original script which had been lost for a period of time, and published it together with a CD containing the recorded dialogues and seven musical pieces. The music from the original score was reconstructed by musicologist Luis Salazar Mejía with the collaboration of musicians Daniel Dorival and Claude Ferrier and the support of cultural promoter Mario Cerrón Fetta, and re-released on November 14, 15, and 16, 2013 at the Teatro UNI in Lima to celebrate its first centenary. The zarzuela included the famous homonymous melody, without lyrics, based on the traditional Andean music of Peru, where it was declared a National Cultural Heritage in 2004. ==Simon and Garfunkel version== {{Infobox song | name = El Cóndor Pasa (If I Could) | cover = El Condor Pasa cover by Sinon & Garfunkel.jpg | alt = | type = single | artist = [[Simon & Garfunkel]] | album = [[Bridge Over Troubled Water]] | B-side = [[Why Don't You Write Me]] | released = September 1970 | format = [[Single (music)|7" single]] | recorded = November 1968 and
November 1969 | studio = | venue = | genre = [[Folk rock]], [[worldbeat]], [[Andean music]] | length = 3:06 | label = [[Columbia Records|Columbia]] | writer = [[Daniel Alomía Robles]] (Music), [[Paul Simon]] (English lyrics), Jorge Milchberg ([[Arrangement]]) | producer = [[Paul Simon]],
[[Art Garfunkel]],
[[Roy Halee]] | prev_title = [[Cecilia (Simon & Garfunkel song)|Cecilia]] | prev_year = 1970 | next_title = [[The 59th Street Bridge Song (Feelin' Groovy)]] | next_year = 1970 | misc = {{External music video|{{YouTube|i6d3yVq1Xtw|"El Cóndor Pasa (If I Could)" (audio)}}}} }} In 1965, the American musician [[Paul Simon]] heard for the first time a version of the melody by the band [[Los Incas]] in a performance at the ''Théâtre de l'Est parisien'' in Paris in which both were participating. Simon became friendly with [[Los Incas]] band, later even touring with them and producing their first US-American album. He asked the band for permission to use the song in his production. The band's director and founding member [[Jorge Milchberg]], who was collecting royalties for the song as co-author and arranger, responded erroneously that it was a traditional Peruvian composition. Milchberg told Simon he was registered as the arrangement's co-author and collected royalties. In 1970, the [[Simon & Garfunkel]] duo covered the Los Incas version, adding some English lyrics which in turn added Paul Simon to the author credits under the song name "El Cóndor Pasa (If I Could)". The instrumental version by Los Incas was used as the base track. They included the song on the 1970 album ''[[Bridge Over Troubled Water]]''. Simon & Garfunkel released their version as a single in the U.S., which reached #18 on the [[Billboard Pop Singles]] chart and #6 on the [[Hot Adult Contemporary|Easy Listening]] chart,{{cite book |title= Top Adult Contemporary: 1961–2001|last=Whitburn |first=Joel |authorlink=Joel Whitburn |year=2002 |publisher=Record Research |page=222}} in fall 1970. This cover achieved major international success and fame. In regard to the Simon & Garfunkel version, [[Daniel Alomía Robles]], Jorge Milchberg, and Paul Simon are now all listed as songwriters, with Simon listed alone as the author of the English lyrics. However, Daniel Alomía Robles was not originally listed as the composer because Jorge Milchberg had told Simon that the song was considered an Andean folk melody. He further stated that he was the registered co-author and arranger of the composition. ===Copyright lawsuit=== In late 1970, Daniel Alomía Robles' son [[Armando Robles Godoy]], a Peruvian filmmaker, filed a successful copyright lawsuit against Paul Simon. The grounds for the lawsuit extended that the song had been composed by his father, who had copyrighted the song in the United States in 1933. Armando Robles Godoy said that he held no ill will towards Paul Simon for what he considered a "misunderstanding" and an "honest mistake".{{cite journal |url=http://www.diariolaprimeraperu.com/online/semana/images/ediciones/pdf/6/6-4.pdf |title=El cine, los libros, la muerte (an interview with Armando Robles Godoy) |language=Spanish |journal=Diario La Primera |author=Juan Carlos Bondy |date=July 6, 2008 |accessdate=2011-07-10 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110710123034/http://www.diariolaprimeraperu.com/online/semana/images/ediciones/pdf/6/6-4.pdf |archivedate=July 10, 2011 |df= }} "It was an almost friendly court case because Paul Simon was very respectful of other cultures. It was not carelessness on his part," said Armando Robles Godoy. "He happened to hear the song in Paris from a vernacular group Los Incas. He liked it, he went to ask the band for permission and they gave him the wrong information. Jorge Milchberg told him it was a traditional folk song from the 18th century and not my father's composition. It was a court case without further complications." Later that year, [[Perry Como]] released a cover of Paul Simon's English version on his album ''[[It's Impossible (album)|It's Impossible]]'', while [[Julie Felix]] had a UK Top 20 hit with it, taking advantage of Simon & Garfunkel's decision not to release their version as a UK single.{{cite web|url=http://kokomo.ca/cd_review/cd_finder/el_condor_pasa_cd_finder.htm |title=Archived copy |accessdate=February 12, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101126073452/http://kokomo.ca/cd_review/cd_finder/el_condor_pasa_cd_finder.htm |archivedate=November 26, 2010 }} Armando Robles Godoy subsequently wrote new Spanish lyrics for the song, taking Paul Simon's version as a reference. ===Chart performance=== {|class="wikitable sortable" |- ! Chart (1970){{cite web|author=Steffen Hung |url=http://swisscharts.com/showitem.asp?interpret=Simon+%26+Garfunkel&titel=El+condor+pasa&cat=s |title=Simon & Garfunkel – El condor pasa |website=Swisscharts.com |date= |accessdate=2016-06-18 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131010072327/http://swisscharts.com/showitem.asp?interpret=Simon%2B&%2BGarfunkel&titel=El%2Bcondor%2Bpasa&cat=s |archivedate=2013-10-10 |df= }} ! Peak
position |- | Australian Kent Music Report | style="text-align:center;"|1 |- |Austrian Singles Chart{{cite web|author=Steffen Hung |url=http://www.austriancharts.at/showitem.asp?interpret=Simon+%26+Garfunkel&titel=The+Boxer&cat=s |title=Simon & Garfunkel – The Boxer |website=Austriancharts.at |date= |accessdate=2016-10-03 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160807160852/http://www.austriancharts.at/showitem.asp?interpret=Simon%20&%20Garfunkel&titel=The%20Boxer&cat=s |archivedate=2016-08-07 |df= }} | style="text-align:center;"|1 |- |Belgian Singles Chart (Flanders) | style="text-align:center;"|1 |- |Dutch Singles Chart | style="text-align:center;"|1 |- |New Zealand | style="text-align:center;"|14 |- |Spanish Singles Chart{{cite book|title=Sólo éxitos: año a año, 1959–2002|last=Salaverri|first=Fernando|date=September 2005|publisher=Fundación Autor-SGAE|isbn=84-8048-639-2|edition=1st|location=Spain}} | style="text-align:center;"|1 |- |Swiss Singles Chart | style="text-align:center;"|1 |- |US ''Billboard'' Hot 100 | style="text-align:center;"|18 |- |US ''Billboard'' [[Adult Contemporary (chart)|Easy Listening]] | style="text-align:center;"|6 |- |West German Singles Chart | style="text-align:center;"|1 |} ==Other versions== *In France, [[Marie Laforêt]] performed her "Sur les chemins des Andes" (aka "Sur le chemin des Andes" aka "La flûte magique") in 1966. It is said to be based on Jorge Milchberg's adaptation. *In 1969 a jazz version was recorded and arranged by [[Don Sebesky]] for [[Paul Desmond]]'s studio album ''[[Bridge over Troubled Water (Paul Desmond album)|Bridge over Troubled Water]]''. *In 1970, Argentinean [[Quena]] virtuoso [[Facio Santillan]] recorded the piece for Riviera in Paris, France. It was a released as a single and on the album Flutes of the Andes Vol. 2. *In 1970, [[Karel Gott]] recorded this song in [[Czech language|Czech]] under the original name ''El Condor Pasa''. The lyrics were written by Jiří Štaidl. *[[Andy Williams]] released a version in 1970 on his album, ''[[The Andy Williams Show (album)|The Andy Williams Show]]''. *In 1970, Malaysian singer and songwriter [[Sarena Hashim]] recorded the song in [[Malay language|Malay]] titled "Bayangan Menjelma" with lyrics written by herself. The song appeared in her 2nd EP, 'Harapan Bersama' and her first LP, 'Ku Datang Lagi'. *Peruvian singer [[Yma Sumac]] recorded this song in 1971 in [[vocalise]] style without lyrics in her last studio album ''Miracles''. *In 1971, [[Paul Mauriat]] and his orchestra covered this song on the album ''El Condor Pasa''. *[[Esther Ofarim]] recorded the song with its original Spanish lyrics for her 1972 self-titled album. *In a 1980 episode of ''[[The Muppet Show]]'', the song was given a parody treatment with nonsense rhymes by [[The Great Gonzo]], earning the mock inspiration of guest star [[Paul Simon]]. *In 1983 [[Jose Feliciano]] recorded for [[motown]] records is personal version with a great guitar flamenco-solo for his Hit spanish LP "Me Enamore" who won a [[Grammy Award]] for best Latin |journal=Theatre Organ |volume=27 |issue=1 |page=19 |issn=0040-5531}} *A Dutch rendering entitled "Bouzouki's Klinken Door De Nacht" was recorded by [[Ciska Peters]] ([[:nl:Ciska Peters|nl]]) in 1984. *[[The Coolies]] cover it on their 1986 album ''dig..?'', along with eight other tongue-in-cheek covers of Simon & Garfunkel classics. *Argentinian pianist, [[Raul Di Blasio]], included "El Cóndor |url=https://www.amazon.com/Spirit-Andes-Gheorghe-Zamfir/dp/B001ECE658/ref=sr_1_18?s=music&ie=UTF8&qid=1447679284&sr=1-18 |title=Gheorghe Zamfir – Spirit of the Andes |website=Amazon.com |date= music|url=http://www.ew.com/article/2014/12/04/wild-director-music|website=[[Entertainment Weekly]]|publisher=[[Time Inc.]]|accessdate=May 15, 2015|date=January 18, 2015}} *In 2016, German Celtic folk Mario Kart Wii |publisher=[[YouTube]] |date=2011-06-11 |accessdate=2017-04-21}} *[[Israel]]i folk duo The Parvarim released a [[Hebrew]] version of the song. *Spanish [[Eurodance]] [[Disc jockey|DJ]], revision.text:
[[File:Fieschi-Morgan-Staurothèque-DT119.jpg|thumb|Fieschi Morgan Staurothèque - early 9th century]] [[File:Reliquary True Cross c800 Byzantine.jpg|thumb|Fieschi Morgan Staurothèque - early 9th century]]
The '''Fieschi Morgan Staurotheke''' is a small [[reliquary]] designed to hold a relic of the [[True Cross|true cross]], it is 1 1/16 x 4 1/16 x 2 13/16 inches (2.7 x 10.3 x 7.1 cm) overall with lid. It is an example of [[Byzantine enamel]]ing. The box is dated to 843 (some scholars speculate an earlier date of 815).<ref name="Cormack 114">{{cite book|last1=Cormack|first1=Robin|title=Byzantine Art|date=2000|publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=0192842110|page=114}}</ref> Both dates hover around the second wave of [[Byzantine Iconoclasm]] from 814–842, allowing this piece to become a lens into the post iconoclastic art. These reliquaries doubled as an [[icon]] in style and purpose. The physical material of icons and the content within the reliquary were believed to contained a spirit or energy. It was believed that reliquaries contained great power, thus explains its preservation throughout the years.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Kitzinger|first1=Ernst|title=Christian Imagery: Growth and Impact|date=1980|publisher=The Metropolitan Museum of Art|page=156}}</ref> There are numerous theories of where this piece was created and its movement. It's currently on display at the [[Metropolitan Museum of Art|Metropolitan Museum]].
==Physical description== The [[wikt:staurotheke|staurotheke]] is made from [[gilded silver]], gold, [[Byzantine enamel|enamel]] worked in [[cloisonné]], and [[niello]]. The front lid depicts Christ on the cross wearing a [[colobium]] (sleeveless tunic) flanked by Mary and Saint John the Theologian. On either side of Christ head there is a sun and moon and Greek text which says "Here is your son...Here is your Mother" and each figure is called out by name; Mother of God, Jesus, and John. Christ eyes are open and appears to be alive which is an important dating factor, as 9th century crucifixion scenes often detailed Christ's eyes closed, a crown of thorns, bleeding hands and feet, and the skull of Adam.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Wilensky|first1=S.F.|title=Pre-Iconoclastic Byzantine Art and the Fieschi-Oppenheim-Morgan Reliquary of the True Cross|date=1981|publisher=Empire State College|page=10}}</ref> Bordering the Crucifixion scene are 14 saints who are depicted subtly different from one another, starting from the top left going counter clockwise they are: Saint Demetrios, [[Saint Eustathios]], [[Saint Lawrence]], [[Saint Luke|Luke]], [[Saint Mark the Evangelist|Mark]], [[Thomas the Apostle|Thomas]], [[James, son of Zebedee|James]], Saint Damiano, Saint Kosmas, [[Saint Gregory I|Saint Gregory the Miracle-Worker]], [[Bartholomew]], [[Matthew Gospel|Matthew]], [[Jude the Apostle|Jude]], and [[Simon the Zealot|Simon]].
Underneath the lid the surface is divided into four parts and created using niello, the top left, the [[Annunciation]]; top right, the [[Nativity of Jesus|Nativity]] and bathing of Jesus; bottom left, the [[Crucifixion]] (which mimics the front lid); and the bottom right, the Anastasis (Christ descent into Hell) scene pulling Adam and Eve out of Hell.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Wilensky|first1=S.F|title=Pre-Iconoclastic Byzantine Art and the Fieschi-Oppenheim-Morgan Reliquary of the True Cross|date=1981|publisher=Empire State College|page=14}}</ref> Greek text within the scenes translates to, "Hail, full of grace!" and "Here is your son...Here is your mother."<ref name=Met>{{cite web|title=The Fieschi Morgan Staurotheke|url=http://www.metmuseum.org/art/collection/search/472562|website=Met Museum|accessdate=6 March 2016}}</ref> The lid was only removed by intimate viewers, so these scenes might have been more privileged.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Kitzinger|first1=Ernst|title=Christian Imagery: Growth and Impact|date=1981|publisher=The Metropolitan Museum of Art|page=155}}</ref> The interior of the box is divided by a [[Patriarchal cross|Patriarchal]] (double cross) walls which create 5 sections. It is believed to have contained a wooden cross relic that would have fit perfectly within the main section, the 4 surrounding compartments would have contained other Holy relics, such as bones, hair, cloth, etc.
Along the sides of the box are 13 saints with halos and a golden latch; [[Saint Anastasios]], [[Saint Nicholas]], [[Saint Platon]], [[Theodore of Amasea|Saint Theodore]], Saint Prokopios, [[Saint George]], Saint Merkourios, Saint Eustrastios, [[Saint Panteleimon]], [[Saint Andrew]], [[John the Evangelist|Saint John]], [[Saint Paul]], [[Saint Peter]].<ref name=Met/> The saints along the sides are represented with great variance, despite the approximately one square inch space, making distinguishes between color of eyes, hair style, and facial hair. The base of the container is gold stamped with a dot pattern into a shape of a Latin cross, with circular or disc shaped ends.
Overall, the box is small in size and packs in many narratives and figures. Its cloisonne is considered crude and lettering is botched for Byzantine standards.<ref name="Cormack 114"/> Other scholars have called it naive and stiff compared to other cloisonné and enamel pieces of that period.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Wilensky|first1=S.F|title=Pre-Iconoclastic Byzantine Art and the Fieschi-Oppenheim-Morgan Reliquary of the True Cross|date=1981|publisher=Empire State College|page=40}}</ref> The primary colors of the reliquary enamel are emerald green, blue, maroon, gold, and white.
==Creation and movement== Artisans were persecuted, like the story of [[Lazarus Zographos|Lazarus]] whose hands were burnt after defying to destroy and renounce his craft. The Fieschi Morgan Staurotheke is an object that offers one perspective of art created after the decline in religious crafts. The trade of skilled artisans needed to be outsourced beyond the Byzantine empire and outside the purge of figurative art. Rome continued to create and explore art techniques and played a role reeducating Byzantine artists. Rome is a source for enamel art as the colors used in the Fieschi Morgan Staurotheke were in production there and the city was a place of refuge for [[wikt:iconophile|iconophiles]].<ref name="Cormack 114"/> It is most popularly believed that this was created in the shadows from iconoclasm or just after iconoclasm in Constantinople.
[[File:True Cross Relic Dimensions.png|thumbnail|Reliquary and True Cross Dimensions]] The reliquary could have arrived in Italy by the [[Crusades|Crusaders]] in 1204, as many precious art pieces entered western Europe.<ref name="Williamson 66">{{cite book|last1=Williamson|first1=G.C|title=The Oppenheim Reliquary and its Contents|date=1913|page=66|url=http://scans.library.utoronto.ca/pdf/1/16/burlingtonmagazi23londuoft/burlingtonmagazi23londuoft.pdf}}</ref> It was also common that monks traveling west would give gifts to the monasteries.<ref name="Wilensky 46">{{cite book|last1=Wilensky|first1=S.F|title=Pre-Iconoclastic Byzantine Art and the Fieschi-Oppenheim-Morgan Reliquary of the True Cross|date=1981|publisher=Empire State College|page=46}}</ref> A theory of the relic being separated from the reliquary was due to its poor craftsmanship or creation by an immature student and was not worthy to house the true cross relic.<ref name="Williamson 66"/> The relic was taken out and worn on a necklace by Pope Innocent IV. Pope Innocent IV presented the relic to his new basilica, San Salvatore di Lavagna, in 1245 (where it still resides) and the box became an heirloom of the Fieschi Family. The relic and reliquary have never been put together. Based on the dimensions presented of the reliquary<ref name=Met/> and cross relic<ref>{{cite book|last1=Dalton|first1=O.M.|title=Byzantine Enamels in Mr. Pierpont Morgan's Collection.|date=1912|publisher=The Burlington Magazine for Connoisseurs 21|page=69}}</ref> here is a diagram that shows that the relic could fit within the reliquary.
Another theory is that the reliquary was never brought to the west but was created in the west. Evidence of enamel coloring and the art practice being revived in Rome supports this theory. In addition, Saint Lawrence, depicted on the reliquary was a popular saint in the west beginning in the 5th century but not in the east until the 10th century.<ref name="Wilensky 46"/>
In April 1887 the box was purchased at an auction by Freiherr Albert Von Oppenheim.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Dalton|first1=O.M.|title=Byzantine Enamels in Mr. Pierpont Morgan's Collection.|date=1912|publisher=The Burlington Magazine for Connoisseurs 21|page=66}}</ref> In 1906 it was purchased by [[J. Pierpont Morgan]] in London and given to the Met Museum in 1913.

{{BLP sources|date=July 2014}} {{use dmy dates|date=July 2014}} {{infobox model | name = Floriana Garo | image = Lola3.jpg | image_size = | caption = | alt = | birth_name = | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1987|02|15|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Durrës]], [[Albania]] | other_names = | nationality = Albanian | occupation = Television presenter, journalist | alma_mater = [[City College of New York]] | height = {{convert|1.80|m}} | hair_color = Brown | eye_color = Brown | measurements = | weight = | dress_size = | collar = | suit = | shoe_size = | agency = | spouse = <!-- {{marriage|name|start|end}} --> | partner = | children = | relatives = Sofokli Garo and Teuta Garo | website = {{URL|florianagaro.al}} }} '''Floriana Garo''' (born 15 February 1987) is an Albanian television presenter and model.
She represented Albania in the [[Miss World 2012]] beauty pageant.<ref>{{cite web| author = Press release | url=http://www.ccny.cuny.edu/news/Floriana-Garo-wins-Miss-Albania.cfm |title= CCNY-Groomed Miss Albania Shoots for the Stars – Floriana Garo, Class of 2011, Is Miss World Contestant | publisher= [[City University of New York]] |date= 24 July 2012 |accessdate= 29 July 2014}}</ref>
Garo is the presenter of the entertainment show ''Jo Vetem Mode'' on [[TV Klan]] and [[weather presenter]] on Albania's [[ABC News (Albania)|ABC News]]. In addition, she has also been the [[brand ambassador]] for Albania's [[Cortefiel]] clothing since 2011.
==Early life and education== Born in [[Durres]], she is the daughter of college professor Sofokli Garo and Teuta Garo, a physician. In 2002, she and her family moved to the United States where she lived for eight years.
Garo is a graduate of the [[City College of New York]] having studied [[international relations]] and played on the university volleyball team, winning Player of the Year in 2007 and 2009. She is fluent in English, Albanian, Italian, and Spanish.
==Career==
===''Jo Vetem Modë''=== [[File:Lola2.jpeg|thumb|180px|left]] “Jo vetem mode”, in English “Not only fashion”, is a lifestyle show in Albania, which airs on national [[TV Klan]]. The 60 minute program, which started on February 16th, 2013 is hosted and written by Floriana Garo. It is currently in its 4th Season with 28.9 shares rating.
“Jo vetem mode” features profiles of Albanian celebrities, athletes and politicians among which the [[First Lady of Albania]], [[Odeta Nishani]], Minister of Defense [[Mimi Kodheli]], Politician/Lawyer [[Spartak Ngjela]], Lazio’s football player [[Lorik Cana]], the captain of the US Olympic Volleyball team [[Donald Suxho]], the famous clothing designer [[Ema Savahl]], supermodel [[Angela Martini]], etc.
“Jo vetem mode” has a great influence in promoting tourism and new cultures by featuring interesting tourist destinations for Albanians to explore as well as promote Albania’s wonderful landscapes. The show explores new and luxurious travel and leisure destinations in Albania and Europe such as Sueno Deluxe resort in Turkey, Radika Ski resort in Macedonia, Queen ELizabeth Cruiseship, Sunshine hotel in Greece, Splendor Hotel in [[Dhërmi]], Albania, etc.
“Jo vetem mode” takes viewers inside some of the most important buildings in Albania such as the Palace of the Brigades, the new Ministry of Culture, Prime Minister’s Office as well as inside the residences of the Ambassador of Brazil and the ambassador of Kuwait in Albania. The program covers the latest fashion and cultural events such as the World Fashion week in Paris, Geraldina Sposa Bridal shows, [[Miss Universe Albania]], the annual Presidential ball, etc. In addition, it informs people of interesting activities to try in Albania such as helicopter rides, horseback riding, paragliding, wine tours and hiking in the Albanian Alps.
“Jo vetem mode” is point of reference for everyone who appreciates beauty, wants to be inspired, and is looking for new and interesting things to do in Albania and beyond. The show is watched by Albanians all over the world through the Digital Platforms and has hundreds of thousands of views on [[Youtube]].
===Other activities=== [[File:Lola1.JPG|thumb|140px|Floriana Garo]] Floriana is the author and host of "Jo vetem mode" lifestyle show on the national TV Klan. Also she is the weather presenter for [[ABC News Albania]].
She represented Albania in Miss World 2012 in Ordos, China. This experience jump started her television career and made her even more well known for the Albanian public. In 2012, Garo presented a concert during the [[100th Anniversary of the Independence of Albania]] in [[Commemorations of Mother Teresa##Mother Teresa in Albania|Nene Teresa Square]] (Mother Teresa Square). She co-presented [[Miss Globe Organisation|Miss Globe]] 2013 along with Gent Bejko and in November 2013, she presented the book fair in Tirana. Garo is the official [[spokesmodel]] for [[Cortefiel]] Albania clothing brand. She has been in various television commercials for this brand.
She modeled for Geraldina Sposa bridal shows in 2012, 2013, and 2014. Garo has been on the covers of "Living", "Icon", "VIP", " Coffee", ''Shije'', ''Mapo Madame'', ''Jeta'' and ''Klan'' magazines.
==Personal life==
Since June 2010, Garo has lived in [[Tirana]]. {{clear}}

It sold over 5 million copies {{Citation needed|date=August 2007}} and won the 1983 [[Shogakukan Manga Award]] for [[children's manga]].{{cite web|url=http://comics.shogakukan.co.jp/mangasho/rist.html |script-title=ja:小学館漫画賞: 歴代受賞者 |publisher=Shogakukan |language=Japanese |accessdate=2007-08-19 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070929094941/http://comics.shogakukan.co.jp/mangasho/rist.html |archivedate=2007-09-29 |df= }} The series was adapted as a popular [[anime]] television show that aired in 1982 in [[Japan]] on Mondays from 7:00pm to 7:30pm.; and in [[Hong Kong]]. In Japanese, the word "Arashi" means "storm". In [[Hong Kong]], the show aired under the title 電子神童, which translates to "Electronic Prodigy". The series was considered [[Cultural icon|iconic]] in [[Asia]] {{Citation needed|date=August 2007}}, since it came at a time when the public was being exposed to [[video games]] for the first time. The [[manga]] and TV series opened the imagination and possibilities of what gaming entertainment was about, while boosting its popularity as a new [[phenomenon]].{{Citation needed|date=August 2007}} ==Story== The story is about a young boy named Arashi Ishino who is obsessed with video games. He would spend all his time trying to beat the games and conquer the local [[Arcade game|arcades]]. He would meet competitors like Satoru Daimonji and Ishii, who would try to out match him with higher scores. At a certain point in each episode, he would display his special skill of unleashing a [[top]] which will spin so fast that both the top and his hands would catch on fire. On release, the spin would land on or near the [[Arcade cabinet|cabinet]] panels, turning the ordinary button into a [[turbo button]] thus giving him a major advantage. His appearance is known for being bucktoothed, and he always wears a hat labeled "Arashi" with a picture of a [[Sprite (computer graphics)|sprited]] alien. ''Game Center Arashi'' was the first animation with a [[gamer]] as the lead character and have the plot revolve around life with competitive gaming. Some of the games featured in the show include [[Space Invaders]], [[Breakout (arcade game)|Breakout]], [[Galaxian]], though they were not explicitly named. Some of Arashi's gaming techniques even have special names like "Blazed Top", "Vacuum Hurricane Shot", "Fish Stance".Clements, Jonathan. McCarthy Helen. [2006] (2006). Arashi's enemy is Arashi?! |- |} ==Additional versions and appearances== {{Refimprove section|date=December 2010}} In 1999, the series spawned a [[PlayStation]] [[novel]] called [[Game Center Arashi R]]. In 2004 [[Microsoft]] [[Tokyo]] used the character of Arashi as a mascot to boost [[Xbox (console)|Xbox]] sales and image. While the 2002 manga [[Arcade Gamer Fubuki]] reused the concept of a powerful gamer in the arcades, and also spawned a TV series of the same name, that show used entirely different characters and plots, modernizing while separating itself from the 1982 counterpart. {{About|the short story collection|other uses|Interzone (disambiguation)}} {{infobox book | <!-- See Wikipedia:WikiProject_Novels or Wikipedia:WikiProject_Books --> | name = Interzone | image = Image:InterzoneCover.jpg | caption = First edition | author = [[William S. Burroughs]] | cover_artist = | country = United States | language = English | genre = | publisher = [[Viking Press]] | release_date = 1989 | media_type = Print (hardback & paperback) | pages = 194 | isbn = 0-670-81347-8 | preceded_by = | followed_by = }} '''''Interzone''''' is a collection of unpublished short stories and other early works by [[William S. Burroughs]] from 1953 to 1958.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.kirkusreviews.com/book-reviews/william-s-burroughs/interzone/|title=INTERZONE by William S. Burroughs {{!}} Kirkus Reviews|language=en-us}}</ref> The collection was first published by [[Viking Press|Viking Penguin]] in 1989, although several of the stories had already been printed elsewhere, including an earlier publication titled ''Early Routines''. The title was inspired by the [[Tangier International Zone|International Zone]] in [[Tangiers]], Morocco, where Burroughs lived for a time and by which he was greatly influenced.
A notable inclusion is "Twilight's Last Gleamings", written in 1938 in collaboration with childhood friend Kells Elvins, and widely thought to be Burroughs' first attempt at fiction. The villain of the piece, Doctor Benway, was to play a pivotal role in ''[[Naked Lunch]]''. (This story differs from another Burroughs piece titled "Twilight's Last Gleamings," which was published in the 1970s collection, ''[[Exterminator!]]''.)
''Interzone'' features many characters and concepts that would manifest themselves in ''[[Naked Lunch]]'', ''[[Nova Express]]'' and others. At one point, Interzone was considered as a title for ''[[Naked Lunch]]''. Moreover, the concluding section entitled "WORD" was part of the original ''[[Naked Lunch]]'' manuscript but was cut during the editing process (according to the introduction by editor [[James Grauerholz]]).<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.goodreads.com/book/show/257582.Interzone|title=Interzone|website=www.goodreads.com|access-date=2018-10-18}}</ref>
Several of the short pieces were adapted into other media. Burroughs recorded the stories "[[The Junky's Christmas]]" and "Spare Ass Annie," which were set to music and released on the album ''[[Spare Ass Annie and Other Tales]]''. "[[The Junky's Christmas]]" was also adapted as an animated film in the 1990s.
== Contents == The book is divided into three sections:
=== Part 1: Stories === # Twilight's Last Gleamings (a different piece from the one in the earlier collection, ''[[Exterminator!]]'') # The Finger # Driving Lesson #[[The Junky's Christmas]] # Lee and the Boys # In the Cafe Central # Dream of the Penal Colony # International Zone
=== Part 2: Lee's Journals === # Lee's Journals # An Advertising Short for Television # Antonio the Portuguese Mooch # Displaced Fuzz # Spare Ass Annie # The Dream Cops # The Conspiracy # Iron Wrack Dream # Ginsberg Notes (a reference to [[Allen Ginsberg]])
=== Part 3: WORD === As noted above, this is a novella-length story that was originally part of the ''Naked Lunch'' manuscript when it was entitled ''Interzone''.

[[File:Вежа Івана Кущника.jpg|thumb|Ivan Kushchnyk Tower]] '''Ivan Kushchnik Tower''' (''{{lang-ru|Башня Иоанна Кущника}}'', ''{{lang-uk|Вежа Іоанна Кущника}}'') — a defensive [[tower]] with a [[Church (building)|church]], part of the [[Kiev Pechersk Lavra]] [[Pechersk Lavra fortification|fortifications]], [[Kiev]], [[Ukraine]].
== Name == A small church built into the defensive tower was consecrated in the memory of [[:ru:Иоанн Кущник|St. John Kushchnik]], who lived in 5th century in [[Bethany (biblical village)|Bethany]] and was considered a saint patron of [[Hetman]] [[Ivan Samoylovych]].<ref name="pamyatky">[http://pamyatky.kiev.ua/streets/lavra/verhnya-teritoriya-lavri-1120-st/svyato-uspenska-kiyevo-pecherska-lavra-muri-oboronni-verhnoyi-teritoriyi-1698-1701-19-stolittya/svyato-uspenska-kiyevo-pecherska-lavra-vezha-ioanna-kushchnika-1696-1701 An account of historic and cultural monuments, Kyiv] ({{lang-uk|Звіт пам'яток історії та культури, Київ.}})</ref>
== Description == The tower is irregular-octagonal in plan, elongated in east-west direction. It is built from brick, covered in white plaster and decorated with profiled [[cornice]]. The tower has three stories covered with tinned [[cupola]] and gilded cross on top. Ceilings of the ground and the first floors were originally wooden, but were later replaced by stone, thus increasing tower fire resistance. The tower height from the ground to the tip of the cross is 25 meters, its other dimensions decrease with height being 9,0 x 7,3 meters at the ground level and 8,5 x 7,0 meters on the first floor level.<ref name="pamyatky" /> Octagonal walls have windows for [[shotgun]]s and small cannons. The tower had a gallery on the monastery side, supported by wooden consoles connected to the general system of defensive walls. The upper tier of the tower has a semicircular window openings. The structure is built in a Kiev style of [[Ukrainian Baroque]].<ref name="pamyatky" />
== History == The tower was built between 1696 and 1701. It was heavily damaged by the great Lavra fire of 1718.<ref name="encyclopedia">[http://www.encyclopediaofukraine.com/display.asp?linkpath=pages%5CK%5CY%5CKyivanCaveMonastery.htm Kyivan Cave Monastery] at [http://www.encyclopediaofukraine.com/ the Encyclopedia of Ukraine]</ref> Historic documents state that three towers with churches, among them St. John Kushchik, were set to be renovated in 1721, along other restorations of Lavra, but the plan was not realized until 1797. However, there was some maintenance before that – in 1785 the tower received a tin roof.<ref name="pamyatky" />
In 1918 the tower was damaged again – this time from the explosion at Zvirinets, then repaired the same year. Major renovations in 20th century were done in 1953<ref name="pamyatky" /> and in 1972. The last one was carried out under supervision of art historian V. Pidgora and architect A. Kulagin. During that renovation the lower walls and vaults of the tower were strengthened, the windows of the top floor and tier under cupola were reopened, and the cross re-gilded.<ref name="pamyatky" />
== See also == * [[Pechersk Lavra fortification]] * [[Russian architecture]] * [[Ukrainian architecture]] * [[Ukrainian Baroque]]
